name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
prompt:
Monocarp has obtained an array a consisting of n integers. The mean of an array with n items is calculated by dividing the sum of all items by n, which involves adding all the numbers together to get a total sum and dividing this sum by n. Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k. Your task is to determine the count of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are removed, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Make sure your solution handles arrays where the elements may include negative numbers.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

Monocarp has obtained an array a consisting of n integers. The mean of an array with n items is calculated by dividing the sum of all items by n, which involves adding all the numbers together to get a total sum and dividing this sum by n. Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k. Your task is to determine the count of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are removed, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Make sure your solution handles arrays where the elements may include negative numbers.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Input


4
4

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[int]:
    """Count valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing them keeps the mean unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the number of elements and the array.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of counts of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = 2 * mean * (n - 2)
        
        count = 0
        element_count = defaultdict(int)

        for num in a:
            element_count[num] += 1

        for i in range(n):
            element_count[a[i]] -= 1
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                element_count[a[j]] -= 1
                if a[i] + a[j] == target_sum:
                    count += 1
                element_count[a[j]] += 1
            element_count[a[i]] += 1

        results.append(count)

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Count pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing these elements keeps the mean unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of integers representing the count of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        target_sum = total_sum * (n - 2) / n
        
        pair_count = 0
        value_count = defaultdict(int)
        
        for value in a:
            value_count[value] += 1
        
        for value in a:
            value_count[value] -= 1
            required_value = target_sum - value
            if required_value in value_count:
                pair_count += value_count[required_value]
        
        results.append(pair_count // 2)  # Each pair is counted twice, so divide by 2
    
    return results

# Input interface

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List
from collections import defaultdict

def count_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Count pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing these elements keeps the mean unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of integers representing the number of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        
        # The sum of the two elements to be removed should be twice the mean
        target_sum = 2 * mean
        
        # Use a hashmap to count occurrences of each element
        element_count = defaultdict(int)
        pair_count = 0
        
        for num in a:
            # Calculate the complement that would form the target_sum with the current number
            complement = target_sum - num
            
            # If the complement exists in the hashmap, it means we can form a valid pair
            if complement in element_count:
                pair_count += element_count[complement]
            
            # Update the count of the current number in the hashmap
            element_count[num] += 1
        
        results.append(pair_count)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append(a)

    # Output interface
    results = count_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing
    these elements maintains the mean of the array.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of integers representing the number of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = mean * (n - 2)
        
        # Count pairs using hashmap
        count_map = defaultdict(int)
        valid_pairs = 0
        
        for num in a:
            # Calculate the required sum of the pair
            required_sum = total_sum - target_sum - num
            # Check if the required number exists in the map
            valid_pairs += count_map[required_sum]
            # Update the map with the current number
            count_map[num] += 1
        
        results.append(valid_pairs)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append(a)

    # Output interface
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

## main.py

from typing import List
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Counts the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing
    these elements keeps the mean of the array unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of results for each test case, representing the count of valid pairs.
    """
    results = []

    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n

        # Calculate the target sum for the remaining elements
        target_sum = mean * (n - 2)

        # Dictionary to store frequency of elements
        freq = defaultdict(int)
        for num in a:
            freq[num] += 1

        count = 0

        # Iterate over each element to find valid pairs
        for i in range(n):
            # Calculate the required sum of the two elements to be removed
            required_sum = total_sum - target_sum - a[i]

            # Decrease the frequency of the current element
            freq[a[i]] -= 1

            # Check if there exists another element to form the required sum
            if required_sum in freq and freq[required_sum] > 0:
                count += freq[required_sum]

        # Each pair is counted twice, so divide by 2
        results.append(count // 2)

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append(a)

    # Output interface
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Counts the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing
    these elements maintains the mean of the remaining elements.

    Args:
        t (int): The number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): A list of test cases, each containing the
            number of elements followed by the elements of the array.

    Returns:
        List[int]: A list of integers where each integer is the count of valid
        pairs for the corresponding test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for case in test_cases:
        n = case[0]
        a = case[1:]
        
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = mean * (n - 2)
        
        # Dictionary to count occurrences of each element
        count_map = {}
        for num in a:
            count_map[num] = count_map.get(num, 0) + 1
        
        valid_pairs = 0
        
        # Iterate over the array to find valid pairs
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                # Calculate the sum of the array without a[i] and a[j]
                current_sum = total_sum - a[i] - a[j]
                
                if current_sum == target_sum:
                    valid_pairs += 1
        
        results.append(valid_pairs)
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append([n] + a)
    
    # Call the function and print results
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the number of valid pairs of indices for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of integers representing the number of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = mean * (n - 2)
        
        # Use a hashmap to store the frequency of each element
        freq = defaultdict(int)
        for num in a:
            freq[num] += 1
        
        count = 0
        
        # Iterate over each element and calculate the required pair sum
        for num in a:
            required_pair_sum = 2 * mean - num
            if required_pair_sum in freq:
                count += freq[required_pair_sum]
                # Adjust for double counting
                if required_pair_sum == num:
                    count -= 1
        
        # Each pair is counted twice, so divide by 2
        results.append(count // 2)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append(a)

    # Output interface
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Count the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing
    these elements keeps the mean of the remaining elements unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    results = []
    
    for a in test_cases:
        n = len(a)
        total_sum = sum(a)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = 2 * mean
        
        # Use a hashmap to store the frequency of each element
        freq_map = defaultdict(int)
        for num in a:
            freq_map[num] += 1
        
        count_pairs = 0
        
        # Iterate over each element and find pairs
        for i in range(n):
            freq_map[a[i]] -= 1  # Decrease frequency as we consider this element
            complement = target_sum - a[i]
            
            # Check if the complement exists in the remaining elements
            if complement in freq_map:
                count_pairs += freq_map[complement]

    return results

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing
    these elements maintains the mean of the array.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[int]]): List of test cases, each containing an array of integers.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of integers representing the number of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for array in test_cases:
        n = len(array)
        total_sum = sum(array)
        mean = total_sum / n
        target_sum = mean * (n - 2)
        
        count = 0
        value_count = {}
        
        for value in array:
            value_count[value] = value_count.get(value, 0) + 1
        
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[i] + array[j] == total_sum - target_sum:
                    count += 1
        
        results.append(count)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append(array)

    # Output interface
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import defaultdict

def count_valid_pairs(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[int]:
    """Count the number of valid pairs of positions [i, j] such that removing them keeps the mean unchanged.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the number of elements and the array.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of counts of valid pairs for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, a in test_cases:
        total_sum = sum(a)
        original_mean = total_sum / n
        
        # Calculate the target sum for the remaining elements
        target_sum = original_mean * (n - 2)
        
        # Dictionary to count occurrences of each element
        element_count = defaultdict(int)
        for num in a:
            element_count[num] += 1
        
        valid_pairs = 0
        
        # Iterate over each element
        for i in range(n):
            # Calculate the required pair sum
            required_pair_sum = total_sum - target_sum - a[i]
            
            # Decrease the count of the current element
            element_count[a[i]] -= 1
            
            # Check if the required pair sum exists in the remaining elements
            if required_pair_sum in element_count:
                valid_pairs += element_count[required_pair_sum]
        
        results.append(valid_pairs)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    # Output interface
    results = count_valid_pairs(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

The key observation is that the sum of the array minus the sum of the two removed elements should be equal to the mean times the number of remaining elements. This can be efficiently calculated using a hashmap to store the frequency of each element and then iterating over pairs to check the condition. This approach ensures we handle large arrays efficiently and correctly manage negative numbers.
requirement analysis:
The task requires identifying pairs of elements whose removal keeps the mean of the array unchanged. This involves calculating the total sum and mean, then determining which pairs of elements can be removed without affecting the mean. The solution must efficiently handle large arrays and multiple test cases.
requirement pool:
- Efficiently calculate the mean and identify valid pairs of elements to remove.
- Ensure the solution handles edge cases, such as arrays with identical elements.
- Optimize the solution for large input sizes.
- Maintain code readability and simplicity.
- Provide detailed comments and documentation for the code.
We will use a mathematical approach to determine the pairs of elements that can be removed without changing the mean. The key observation is that removing two elements should not affect the mean, which implies that the sum of the removed elements should be equal to twice the mean of the original array. We will iterate over all pairs of elements and check this condition efficiently using a hashmap to store the frequency of elements.

The solution must efficiently handle large arrays and multiple test cases, and correctly process arrays with negative numbers.

We will implement a function that calculates the mean of the array and then iterates through pairs of elements to check if their removal maintains the mean. We will use efficient iteration and arithmetic operations to handle large arrays quickly. The solution will be compatible with negative numbers by ensuring the arithmetic operations are correctly handled.
requirement analysis:
The task requires identifying pairs of elements in an array that can be removed while maintaining the mean of the remaining elements. The solution must efficiently handle up to 200,000 elements across multiple test cases, including arrays with large and negative numbers. The output must be formatted correctly for each test case.
requirement pool:
- Efficiently handle large input sizes up to 200,000 elements.
- Correctly identify and count valid pairs of elements to remove.

We will iterate over each test case, calculate the total sum of the array, and then determine the mean. For each pair of elements, we will check if removing them keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to the original mean. We will use a dictionary to efficiently count occurrences of elements to optimize the search for valid pairs.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
